pros: As an intern or senior-level employee, you are likely to have a positive experience at CSIS, but this company can be an absolute nightmare for junior-level employees. Your experience as a junior staffer, however, is largely dependent on the director of the team you will be joining. However, CSIS is notorious for hiring toxic, depraved, egotistical directors. There is room for professional growth and upward movement, but really pointless when employees aren't being treated with basic dignity/respect. DLIA is taking "steps" to address the lack of diversity, but it's all at face value. No institutional changes are being made under the current director, Nicole Aandahl, who is known throughout the. center for her unprofessionalism.
cons: Other people's reviews about sexual harassment and straight-out bullying of junior employees are true. There are horror stories from far too many employees who have had very negative experiences with the Human Resource team, the director of my program, and several other senior fellows. Concerns of sexual harassment, bullying, and racial discrimination are often taken to the HR department, but no action is taken. HR does not follow SOPs, which is especially alarming. The person reporting this behavior is instead punished and/or silenced with the threat of losing their job. Absolutely deplorable behavior that you wouldn't expect out of an organization like CSIS.

pros: CSIS is one of the most prestigious think tanks in the world, and on a day-to-day basis you see both U.S. and foreign officials and thinkers coming to CSIS to add their perspectives to the intellectual mix. There are no predetermined right answers in this bipartisan environment, and there's a lot of great discussion. Everyone I've worked with is passionate about making a positive difference in their field. There's a great DEI program (5-star effort), and the Center is making progress on hiring more senior women, although progress on hiring senior-level researchers of color is slower.
cons: Like all institutions, there's a bit of bureaucracy--in the CSIS case, there are slight fundraising and territorial tensions between different research programs, but that is somewhat ameliorated recently by serious initiatives to tackle "horizontal problems" by collaborating across multiple research programs. There's not enough room for senior-level research staff to move upwards, since top posts are generally hired from outside.

pros: Unparalleled name recognition. Opens doors to many places in industry and great starting point for grad school, or careers in policy consulting.
cons: Getting in could be difficult. Lots of networking required and selection process is a bit random (having read applications myself). Pro tip: referrals from notable IR/regional studies professors or other industry experts almost always guarantee you a spot over submitting your resume through the online portal. Relatively low-paying entry level job, however. There is a clear lack of diversity among the staff too, but it is to be expected as in most think tanks in DC.

review_title: Good satisfying work, disappointing career ladder prospects and compensation
pros: Working at CSIS feels like I'm making a difference. My voice and opinions are respected. My supervisor challenges me to do my best work, but is fair, compassionate, and flexible. The research I do is fascinating. I am given opportunities to come up with and implement creative ideas. There is decent work-life balance. My colleagues are kind, intelligent, honest, hardworking, and generally a joy to talk to. It's generally a flat organization, so I feel that I can have conversations with folks at the director level, even in other programs, relatively easily.
cons: My high quality hard work has not been rewarded monetarily or in terms of increased benefits. As a Research Associate, I see a very narrow career ladder up to the associate fellow level, much less the director level. Last year, my raise was "on the high side," but it was still less than inflation, so I feel like my standard of living is decreasing, even though I am contributing to the team's high productivity and value. My program has run a net surplus for the center and published more content than most other programs, yet I am not being rewarded for contributing to the program's high performance.

review_title: Good organization, good culture, working on shortfalls
pros: Good organization doing good work, Dr. Hamre's steady hand has led the Center through COVID well and they are actively working on improving conditions and compensations.
cons: A bit of an old school mentality in terms of remote work, siloed work environments provide wildly differing experiences amongst junior staff

pros:
- Some of the people are incredible; you will work with many bright, kind, and interesting people 

- The content CSIS produces is world-class. Being in this environment in any capacity has its benefits. 

- They increased their baseline pay for junior staff, which is nice but still low as is normal for nonprofits.
cons:
- Management is everything in an organization (most people leave their jobs due to poor management), and CSIS largely fails from the top down. The "9th floor" is a boys club with an aging CEO who is completely out of touch with most employees. He's treated by higher-ups like a deity and casts an authoritarian shadow across the organization. He does not inspire motivation and the company would benefit from a younger and more relatable CEO who cares about junior staff. 

- The completely decentralized nature of CSIS means management is almost entirely dependent on who your director is. Many are wonderful, but they are outnumbered by arrogant directors who create a toxic work environment and the 9th floor couldn't care less. This is not conducive to productivity or growth; bullying, passive-aggressive, gaslighting, and incompetent management that oscillates between laziness/neglect and micromanagement is commonplace and at a level that is frankly shocking. 

- Many teams experience burnout and unnecessarily long hours while others have healthy working hours and a positive culture—it's entirely dependent on your director, which is the nature of CSIS in a nut shell. Young and otherwise healthy young people should not be experiencing back problems because they are strapped to a chair from 8:30 AM to 7 PM most days and feel the need to guilt trip people who want to leave after completing work around 5:30. CSIS is impactful, but its a nonprofit—not the Pentagon or White House. (For those reading this review and considering employment at CSIS, take the intern reviews with a grain of salt. They don't capture the full picture since interns work shorter hours and aren't exposed to everything in the org).

pros:
This is a prestigious institution as well as being a generally very good place to work, (though experience probably varies based on which program one works in and one's background, see below on decentralized structure.) I personally had a very good experience, supported by my peers and supervisors, and given plenty of opportunities to move my career forward. Remote work is hard on every institution and employee, but CSIS did a pretty good job of keeping people engaged, seeking their opinions/needs/feedback, listening seriously, and often coming through with generous solutions. It's a very good jumping-off point coming out of college or graduate school.

CSIS has a very decentralized structure, which enables programs to really dive into the research they want to do (and can find funding for.) When I was there, leadership was just beginning to work out some oversight mechanisms to smoothen out event schedules, keep an eye on the overall message and timing, etc. but overall it's a light touch. Similarly, while there are some hard and fast rules as to what certain types of employees should be doing, to a great extent young researchers can pitch and carry out amazing projects as long as their supervisor supports them.
cons:
First, it's important to know that think tanks as a whole don't tend to be designed to employ young people for a long time and elevate them through the ranks, so the junior and mid-level employee needs to plan on seeking new experiences after two or three years. 

As for CSIS in particular, its decentralized nature has some drawbacks, particularly in incentives that subtly set programs in competition with each other for funding, speakers, etc. There are pros and cons to this model, and the cons are that sometimes things get confusing or weird for the junior/midlevel staff to try and navigate properly. 

The decentralization also results in certain institutional problems being difficult to resolve. For example, I am amazed that so few (when I was there, maybe as much as 1% of the total) Fellows and Research Associates were Black American or Hispanic American. One reason for that might be that each program hires independently, so it's difficult to pressure any one program to seek diversity in hiring.

review_title: Spotty career development for sub-minimum wage pay working for corporations
pros: If you want to work for a specific federal agency and find an expert who has experience and connections there, working on a team for them gives you a big leg up in that application process. The Institute does have *some* value to the ecosystem that is DC - mainly, in my opinion, by introducing overview research to interested people through many media - but I can't think of many reasons why people would want to *work* here.
cons:
I think there are three major cons to working with CSIS.

(1) From an employment point of view, they rarely keep their side of the labor agreement. From talking with other interns and new employees, many are promised that if they take low wages (many that are sub-minimum wage), experts will give them lots of career advice and connections so that after your tenure, you will have many opportunities. Plain and simple, this does not happen for 75% of people I met. Most end up having to find opportunities completely on their own. The main reason to take an entry or intern level position here would be for good experience, mentorship, and connections. The only thing you get is experience, but most of that can be attained by just reading reports and going to events. From a transactional point of view, there's little reason to work here; only do if you know for certain that a certain team or expert has a track record of really investing in younger staff development.

(2) The culture is overly professional and militaristic in its strictness. This probably stems from the CEOs background in the military but is totally unwarranted in a research environment. You will be reprimanded for not wearing a suit AND tie everyday, for being even 5 minutes late, and -- to my worst surprise -- for asking questions to experts. I was specifically told that CSIS is not an environment where I'm allowed to raise questions (privately, too, not publicly) of an expert's research. It's a heads down environment everyday. Considering the wage, industry, and CSIS's own outward facing branding of being innovative, this is totally out of place and ineffective towards its research goals.

(3) I met many young people who joined the institute out of a hope that research can help improve some aspect of global society. Many left jaded. CSIS may be nonpartisan as a whole, but its teams are small and often individually dependent on funding. This means that the few funders of each team have a disproportionate say in driving research agenda and (in private meetings) not-so-subtly indicating what kinds of conclusions they hope to see from research. There *is* a decent amount of truly nonpartisaned research being done, but a *very* significant portion is a distorted version of corporate propaganda. This is why some elected representatives have called for think tank donations to be made public. I became jaded for working in the think tank space - but I'm still hoping to find other avenues for change.

If your goal is to do research or drive positive change in the world, you won't have very much opportunities at CSIS, even if you have a few. For the wages and 1950s corporate culture, it's clear that this institute isn't worth most people's time. You might as well go for a consulting firm, or the research arm of a large bank, where you at least have the pay to match the poor workplace conditions.

review_title: In a bottom up org, it depends on who you work for
pros:
Depending on who you work for... 
You have the opportunity to do a lot of substantive research, and interact with people at a very senior level. Your ability to influence  the actual product definitely depends on who you work for, and what kind of boss they are. Similarly, content is driven by what you get funded for. Being part of the CSIS community means a lot of open doors, both inside the institution (everyone is pretty friendly and willing to sit down for a chat) and outside (given the institution's reputation).
cons:
Regardless of who you work for, all junior staff work incredibly hard for not a lot of money (pretty common in DC, and especially in non-profits). The actual environment, though, depends greatly on who you work for, since most of the programs are pretty self-sustaining. The funding model at CSIS means that there isn't really any metric of effectiveness/measure of success/basis of accountability other than raising your own money; this means that the quality of management, the work/life balance, and other things are greatly dependent on your boss and often unsupported. 
There is no training-- just a "buddy system"-- which means you learn most of it through trial and error. It is not a very collaborative work environment, particularly between programs, and can feel isolating.

review_title: Brilliant colleagues and work, major institutional flaws
pros:
-The high-quality work and output of the Center is incredible. Staff members are intelligent, down to earth and work extremely hard to put the Center at a great stature.
-Benefits are decent, pay should be a little higher but isn't bad compared to similar organizations
-Lots of free food
cons:
-The Center is so extremely decentralized that executive management has little to no involvement in what's going on in each program. That means that bad directors and poor management run rampant, and your entire experience depends on which program you work for and who your director is. 
-The executive leadership team is understaffed, overworked, and favor some programs over others, so opportunities for change and problems/issues get stuck with them where little to no action gets taken.
-The Center prioritizes its research programs instead of its administrative programs. In turn, admin programs can end up being disorganized, frantic and flailing at times, which makes no sense, since they are the backbone of the organization.
-There is practically no company culture or sense of unity among the Center. Programs can get cliquey and many people don't know each other or what anyone works on.

review_title: Great place for students and recent grads!
pros: CSIS is an amazing place to work for young adults, especially students or recent graduates, who are looking to get to know their field better and meet some of the most important people that advise the government. The atmosphere is incredibly active all of the time, and the upper-level staff, including President Hamre himself, are dedicated to fostering a good experience for interns, helping them develop professionally through seminars and workshops. Because it is not expected for interns to continue working at CSIS after their period has finished, the staff really wants to teach them how to utilize their skills and newfound knowledge to develop professionally anywhere.
cons: At a think thank there are generally only jobs at the bottom and the top, so when you are an intern, it feels sometimes like you aren't doing that much important work. You may feel that your work is tedious and you don't get a lot of acknowledgement specifically on your research, but this is the nature of the job.

pros: Everyday you are surrounded by fantastic content.  The amount you can learn working here, from your program and others, is amazing.  And they really do support you learning as much as you want/can. I will say though, I have an incredible boss that is very supportive of my efforts and invested in my progress.  I'm sure other bosses at CSIS are like this, but having only worked for him, I can't speak for every other program.  Last Dr. Hamre, the President and CEO of CSIS, is an outstanding and inspiring figure.
cons: If you are a media person, it's not the ideal place to work - as media is not the central priority.  You can learn a lot and get creative projects thrown your way, but I think there is a ceiling for growth if you are a media professional.  Also if you are doing strictly media, you get stuck filming a lot of events (setting up breaking down) and uploading them online.  These tasks get monotonous very fast.

pros:
-lots of opportunities for interns to develop their skills, like Debate Clinics, brown bag lunches with the professionals at CSIS, and opportunities to meet with high level thinktank, government, NGO leaders during events
-my supervisor encouraged us to attend thinktank events around DC, so I went to quite a few every week and learned a lot about the different trends
-opportunities to publish in CSIS "New Perspectives" journal for young professionals
-great place to meet and interact with leading professionals in the field among CSIS staff!
-chance to conduct your own research
-CSIS is a top notch thinktank and well-known, so it looks great to have interned here
cons:
-low stipend, but some departments don't pay interns at all, so it's good to be paid even if it's a small amount
-positions for research assistants/program assistants don't open up very frequently (at least when I was there). you need to have good timing.

pros: Talented coworkers, great networking, exciting and interesting environment.
cons: The pay is extremely low, the hours are very long. Leadership will frequently let go of two positions and "reorganize" by consolidating work into one position so that the employee is left doing two full time jobs without adequate compensation. Leadership does not treat lower level staff with respect. H.R. does not enforce any kind of uniform standards across all departments. There are large disparities in pay and position title between people with similar qualifications and responsibilities across departments. They also will frequently give people a lower title than there actual responsibilities merit to justify paying the employee less money. Dr. Hamre is a wonderful CEO but he is shielded from many of the less than ideal situations that arise in the lower departments.

pros: People are smart and passionate about their subject areas. Great young professionals culture.
cons: Senior leadership do not know everyone (including those who are higher up) despite being a small organization. There is largely no management or accountability for senior leadership, which means directors can treat their staff however (poorly) they’d like. Some directors have received formal HR complaints regarding serious matters upon which no action is taken. No formal training orientation for junior staffers, and work is siloed so they can often be left flailing if they don’t have other strong team members. Directors are prone to throwing hissy fits and are territorial about work. Many directors don’t provide any opportunity beyond very basic administrative work (though this depends very much on your director).

pros: CSIS provides excellent opportunities to jump into your subject area, conduct research on a wide range of issues, and interface with policymakers in the U.S. government and U.S. Congress.  The work is varied and interesting.
cons: The funding model is broken.  You spend a lot of your time trying to raise money (often competing with other CSIS programs), with virtually no internal support from the development team.  The management is disconnected from day to day operations, unless you work for a favored program.  The back office is overworked, hampering day-to-day operations.  The organization appears to be de-prioritizing research in favor of hosting conferences that are increasingly light on content.

review_title: Generally a good place for an early career job
pros: Many workshops and career development opportunities.  Surrounded by foreign policy experts--allows for networking opportunities and ample learning opportunities. If you can find the time to attend events for other program areas, they offer a great learning opportunity. Exposure to government agencies such as USAID, State Department, Department of Defense, as well as contractors.
cons: CSIS is very decentralized in terms of operations, which means that each person's experience depends heavily on which program he or she works for and which program directors and fellows he or she works with. Pay is low. Lots of administrative and event planning tasks.

pros: Think tanks hold prestige and CSIS is no different.  The employees are mostly alright people.
cons:
A basic manager position at Target pays more than most positions at CSIS.  Program coordinators and research assistants tend to stay much longer than I would expect it to be economically feasible in a city like DC.  These positions do not have upward mobility within CSIS as research fellows are recruited from individuals in government who can bring projects/funding with them.  I was able to leave and start at an entry level position in government with a salary comparable to a CSIS director--which as you can see on glassdoor is not an impressive amount.

I would advise international students to avoid CSIS as, beyond the poor salaries, they will not sponsor H-1B and I don't think an internship here will give them a leg up elsewhere.

review_title: One of the better internships available to grow political research network and skills
pros:
Everybody is very professional and friendly.
Access to a wide variety of conferences held by CSIS and other organizations in the DC area.
Network at these events and make sure to attend as many as you can.
cons:
Not so much a con but you're still an intern and when the research associates are busy, you will be expected to do some of the more tedious work.  But they do much of it as well and tend to avoid asking interns to do such things if they can.

Most internships at think tanks are unpaid.

pros: Chance to gain experience in the international affairs field; smart, knowledgeable colleagues; opportunities to publish
cons: Despite the number listed on Glassdoor, there appears to be no pay for the vast majority of interns here, regardless of your background and skills. (Keep this in mind if/when applying.)

review_title: Great organization overall, but YMMV depending on your program
pros: Hard-working, fast-moving environment that attracts very qualified, capable people. CSIS produces top quality research, attracts amazing speakers, and has real influence in the policy community. Depending on your program, junior/mid-level staff can  have a significant amount of research, writing and management responsibility.
cons: Many programs have to work hard to make budget every year, so the financial stress level can be high depending on your program. The operations departments are relatively small, so sometimes it can be difficult to get answers to administrative questions and there is not as much opportunity for collaborative work with different program areas as there could be.

job_title: Program Coordinator & Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
Access to extremely smart and interesting people. 
Opportunities to research, write, develop new skills.
Engaging, dynamic work environment.
Challenging assignments, many chances to try new things and improve at them.
cons:
Limited mid-career options - large early career staff and late career staff, slim opportunities to advance from the former to the latter. Most people leave to work in both the private/public sector before being eligible for the senior staff. 
Pay is decent for the industry, but it's still fairly low considering how talented most people working here are. A lot of what you get is in the exposure, experience, and connections in DC.

pros: This is a great place to work as a junior staffer, it's a great way to enter the DC policy space. Interesting research, transferrable skills, and good colleagues.
cons: The institution has serious management problems - the central programs (finance, development, HR, etc) are all unreliable and chaotic. Because the work of junior staff intersects with these programs on a daily basis, the quality of your experience here will suffer (especially if you're in charge of budgets).

pros: CSIS always has something happening and every week was something interesting. I worked on the corporate side but got to attend most of the events and just seeing all the work they put in to get their event up and running is amazing.
cons: I noticed in the department I worked in, it was very process oriented in a bad way. There were multiple steps to every task and it felt like things took so long to be completed.

pros: Interesting work, sometimes you can be busy which gives you a sense of purpose, my program is incredibly supportive of me taking time off to interview at other places.
cons: I started interning there so I could eventually sustain a job. Full time positions are not plentiful and sometimes the work will make you lose a little steam because interns are everywhere. But I will say the opportunity is what you make of it.

review_title: If you're going to work here, be strategic...
pros:
- Establishment has a well-known name.
- Can be a good stepping-stone to something else.
cons:
- VERY top-down! Be prepared to have no voice or influence.
- Fine for 1-2 years as a junior staffer, but pay is low and they will not invest in you, help you grow, or help you with your job hunt (unless you get lucky with a good director). 
- Very poor management.
- Under developed processes and systems...most things are made up as you go along.

pros: Lots of exposure to DC and great networking opportunities; also very good chances to learn about the field in general and the issue area that my group focused on
cons: Very director-focused, and programs tend to live or die by the director. Also, the program staff that managed the interns did not receive any support or training from HR, and this did not know how to be effective intern managers.

pros: Great people, very intellectually stimulating environment.  Flexible work environment, willing to consider various ideas for support strategies.  opportunities for travel to various points around the globe.
cons: don't really have anything negative to say.  Pay could be higher, I suppose.  Fairly limited opportunities for advancement to higher levels, but  to some extent, it is what you make it.

review_title: Recommended if you're pursuing a career in international security/relations
pros:
You're surrounded by really smart people, develop a good network, and you learn a lot about international relations and security issues.
As it's a non-profit, you need and learn to do a lot of the project processing things on your own.  You can find good mentors though, if international relations/security is  where you want to build your career in.
cons: High turnover especially with the younger staff, pay isn't that great since it's a non-profit organization, long hours

review_title: Great work experience and well recognized, Should hopefully lead to something promising
pros: It is a great experience, and the work you get to do there is truly rewarding. I'm extremely proud of my work and time there, and am sad I could not have continued at CSIS with pay.
cons: I felt when i was there depending on what project you were associated with, there was a varied amount of workload and expectations. There also are not very many positions for jobs.

pros: The staff that work at the center are great, there are excellent leadership opportunities, and amazing events that go on at the center every day
cons: My internship was unpaid, although starting in the fall all interns will receive a stipend. The tasks that I were given were not the most challenging.

review_title: 'you knew what this was'; have no disillusions
pros: Great to have on resume, publication opportunity, knowledgeable and well connected staff, strong springboard for career, free lunch
cons: pay is on lower end of median for middlers, even worse for interns who get paid little to nothing to do the work of middlers, few growth opportunities

job_title: Program Coordinator & Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Great experience and organizational culture, access to experts and ability to have a direct impact on foreign policy issues. Many aspects of the job vary depending on the program you work for.
cons: Can be high stress at times, and pay is not always commensurate with amount of responsibility. The nature of the think tank environment means that there is not a lot of opportunity to advance which results in high turnover at lower levels within the organization.

review_title: Great place to gain experience, people are friendly.
pros: As an internship, it's a great way to network with people, learn about political research, and learn about event management with senior political figures.  CSIS apparently fill nearly half of their staff positions from interns.  The people that work their recognize it's an unpaid internship and make sure you know they value your contribution.
cons: The internships are unpaid and there seems to be an expectation that you will work a full work week.

pros: CSIS does a much better job at building a community than some other think tanks. Although I was only there a short time, I still keep in touch with my old boss, who has helped me out so much with my career. With the exception of a few people, I found everyone pretty approachable and easy to talk to. This is a great place to make connections. I also got my name on several publications.
cons: Almost all internships are unpaid.

pros: Great external reputation with large global audience.
cons: Hires through network, more focused on who you know than what you know, poor annual salary increase, huge pay discrepancy between senior/junior staff, fundraising focuses on institution and not programs, somewhat of a boys club

pros:
The work you're doing feels extremely important
Working with leaders at the top of your interest area
Nice building 
Generally good CSIS-wide activities
cons:
Extreme stuffiness due to hoity-toity types walking in and out all day
Relatively low pay, but not by DC standards 
Occasional tedious work (intern work)

pros: Most think tanks in D.C. do not pay their interns so the fact that CSIS does, is a huge pull for them. It also creates a very diverse work environment. Interns are able to conduct research with and without supervision and are encouraged to attend both internal and external events.
cons: Despite being one of the only places in the international affairs world that pays their interns, they should still pay them more.

pros: CSIS is a very well-known and respected brand within the policy community, so its a great resume-builder.
cons: CSIS is broken up into a number of different programs, and each program runs essentially completely independently of one another. Because of this, the employees experience really depends on their program's director - from their workload to their work/life balance to their vacation policies to their salary.

pros:
There is ample opportunity for studying/writing material pertinent to your field.
You have the ability to network in your desired career field.
cons:
There is always room for lateral movement within CSIS but not vertical movement easily.
Hierarchy plays a big role within the organization.

review_title: Superb atmosphere, great people, excellent experience
pros:
Lots of research, event coordination & writing experience
Very friendly and engaging co-workers
Chance to attend conferences and meet speakers from a wide range of professional backgrounds
cons: Internship is unpaid - but if you are an undergraduate or recent college grad looking for professional experience and a resume boost, this is one of the best places to be.

review_title: Great organization - a fabulous stepping stone for a career in international public service
pros:
You'll meet amazing people
When you demonstrate efficacy in your job, your responsibilities grow
The organization has a very flat culture
The network is unparalleled in the IR field
cons: The fundraising woes that all non-profits experience are apparent at CSIS as well. Additionally, when I was there, there was very little opportunity to move from junior staff positions to mid-level positions internally.

pros: Ability to be part of a global team, accessibility to many opportunities, people, networks, events. Travel opportunities. Good retirement benefits - match after two years of service. Very diverse and stimulating place to work.
cons: Very low salary, lack of strong leadership and management.

pros: You will be responsible for a variety of project management tasks. Interaction with high-level government officials and few IR "celebrities." Plenty of eager interns.
cons: The budgets are always tight and salaries are low. The offices are small and there is a good change that  you will end up in a cubicle.

pros:
Engaging work environment and colleague
Good ethics at workplace
Good working environment
One of the few DC workplaces that pay to interns
Good upper management
cons:
Little prospects to be hired as a full time for interns
Must be willing to do some grunt work (may not be necessarily bad ; you may learn something- e.g. making coffee, copies, assistance for conferences, etc.)

review_title: Great think tank that can open up the world of Washington to junior staff
pros:
Get to work on projects of consequence
Access to world-class scholars, government officials, etc.
Smart and dedicated co-workers
Good camaraderie among junior staff
Ability to work across programs if one demonstrates proper knowledge and interest
cons: Junior staff hit a ceiling from which they usually cannot be promoted

pros: Brilliant research directors, fantastic network opportunities, and unparalleled exposure to the foreign affairs community.
cons: Shortsighted management, lack of institutional support for projects and implementation, terrible salaries with little opportunity for advancement.

pros: Wonderful internship support system. Great way to get connected. Never felt like I was treated like the run of the mill coffee intern. I was always involved in top notch projects.
cons: My department head was wonderful, but there are other department heads who treat interns coldly

pros: Extremely flexible requirements, especially for an intern. They give you every opportunity to grow and there are great opportunities for interns to go full time as program coordinators or research assistants.
cons: If you're not careful, it's easy to be forgotten about. You just need to stay proactive.

pros: It's a great place for internship. A lot of events and research going on. It's a perfect place to learn while building your career. I would highly recommend it.
cons: Dress code can be too formal. We don't have casual Friday as many other 21st century organizations do.

review_title: Experience entirely dependent on one's program/supervisor
pros: Organization does some genuinely interesting work; great name recognition; interesting events that bring in renowned speakers, participants, etc.
cons:
- Negligible oversight of how programs are managed and junior staff treated
- Decentralized model enables and exacerbates systemic issues
- Limited room for junior staff growth

review_title: Great place to get started in the policy world
pros: Hands on internship, friendly junior staff, great place to use as a launching point to creating a network in DC
cons: There's a limit to how much you can dig into any internship, and there's very little way to get hired at CSIS full-time after

review_title: Great place full of very friendly and engaging people.

CSIS provides career betterment seminars for junior and intern level staff.

cons: Pay is tough to live on in the D.C. area.

review_title: Great experience working on Southeast Asia and Pacific foreign policy
pros: Great people. Interesting work. Flexible enough to allow you to research and write about issues of interest in Southeast Asia and the Pacific. Events bring in a wide range of senior officials from around Asia.
cons: Social media work can wear thin.

pros: Incredible smart and engaging coworkers. Nonpartisan analysis to real threats. Limited grunt work.
cons: None. This internship was amazing

pros: Great work environment with lots of energy; majority young people so good position for young professionals
cons: Can get boring at times simply researching; must really have a passion for research to consider working there full time (as I'm sure is the case in all such positions at think tanks)

pros:
Free food

The best example of Peter principle there ever can be. Management out is here terribly incompetent—a result of people being promoted to jobs they aren't qualified for

pros: CSIS is a good environment to work in. It provides an opportunity for growth and professional development especially especially in the operations side.
